title: 113_s274
content: The "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act" is the short title of the legislation. It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The "Children Eating Well Act" defines terms such as elementary school, local educational agency, secondary school, and State educational agency according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It also defines "programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education" as initiatives that enhance students' ability to choose and consume healthy foods, consider various influences on healthy eating, and provide education for making healthy eating decisions. The "Children Eating Well Act" emphasizes the importance of using scientifically sound and developmentally appropriate nutritional materials supported by the most recent Dietary Guidelines for Americans. Professional development programs are also included for teachers, school staff, and food service workers. The "Children Eating Well Act" includes professional development programs for teachers, school staff, and food service workers to promote healthy eating and nutrition in schools. The "Children Eating Well Act" includes programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education. Each local educational agency receiving assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. This may include integrating such programs throughout the school day and using educational materials to emphasize healthy eating. The programs in schools should focus on promoting healthy eating habits, including knowledge of various healthy foods, a balanced diet and lifestyle, integrating healthy eating with physical activity, and improving student skills related to nutrition without emphasizing weight loss. Schools should also periodically monitor their efforts in this area. The local educational agency must consult multiple viewpoints in developing programs for promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. This may include consulting with families, students, school officials, and community members, as well as working with organizations with nutrition expertise. State and local health departments, the Society for Nutrition Education and Behavior, community organizations, and farm groups provide guidance for developing and implementing programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. Collaboration with government authorities like Team Nutrition and State agencies is sought for technical assistance in designing school-based programs. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for nutrition education in schools, including working with wellness councils, integrating programs with school wellness policies, and providing professional development. Each State educational agency must comply with these requirements to receive assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The Secretary of Education requires State educational agencies to submit periodic reports on nutrition education programs. An inter-agency task force will review and recommend effective nutrition education programs for schools. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
